Hermes: Offensive trickster (focused on dealing damage and dodging)
Apollo: Defensive melee tank (focused on blocking damage and regenerating health)

reviewText: Alright so this game will at times seem rough around the edges. It's graphics are dated, and it is a bit glitchy at times. However this game despite its low grades and sub-par reviews is actually excellent in many more ways than it falls short. The story/plot will be the best part of this hidden gem, the way you interact with fellow heros and even NPC's have an actual affect on your story. Said decisions will determine how the path before you will turn either this way or that. Dialogue is actually very well written and combined with what I feel like is an excellent cast of voices that bring at times sorrow, anger, humor, and even hope. Another benefit is that armor and weapons do not appear in a menu that shows stats or numbers, Instead you find rare items throughout your journey that you can choose between to fit your combat style. The screen is streamlined, no health bars or armor condition only you and the game. Take too much damage and you die, however dodging blocking and using abilites and GOD POWERS aid you in a world ever growing with greater threats. Once you are critically injured the edges of the screen turn red  you will then move slower, also you block and attack less effectively. You will always carry three weapon types a spear, sword, mace and of course a shield. Traveling from different points is actually very original, I wont spoil the surprise completely but lets just say you also get a ship, I will say no more on that. When you upgrade your skills such as god powers and striking force or even blocking and healing, you do so by sacrificing you deeds at the altars of the gods. You will have four patrons but knowing which they are I will leave to you to find out. From top to bottom I feel this game is gold, maybe thats biased because I enjoy slash games much more that FPS. The best piece of advice I can give to fix crashing issues is to run the game then open task manager then go to details, then set CPU affinity for ROTA for only one core. It will be CPU 0 if you have multi core processor. You can tell that a low budget studio with great aspirations and strong work ethic put everything they had into this, so I humbly ask if you are considering this title than please purchase  and undertake the quest that challenged the limits of the gods themselves.

reviewText:
GOOD: Interesting setting based on Greek mythology, and an original levelling system whereby you dedicate your accomplishments (completing quests, defeating enemies etc...) to the gods, which gets you points to spend on combat abilities. You also gain the gods favour through dialogue choices, and this helps tie the roleplaying aspect to the combat - if you want to unlock the abilities of war god Ares, it helps to roleplay Jason as aggressive for example.

BAD: The game is short and fairly linear; although the dialogue options affect your character development, there is not much choice in how the quests play out, apart from which order you attempt them in. The combat is also pretty simple and gets a bit repetitive by the end. Finally, if you know anything about the actual Greek myths, you may be disappointed with the games interpretation/butchering of them!

UGLY: This game has a lot of bugs, i had CTD's (though there are fixes on the discussion page that helped) and problems with the audio; weird distortions and sometimes it would cut out temporarily (make sure subtitles are ON!)

Overall i enjoyed it, i didn't mind the linearity or simple combat too much, and it has moments of real creativity. Its nothing groundbreaking, but if you can deal with the occasional CTD, for £5 I'd say its worth a shot

Long story short: The game is good, it has some minor flaws but overall it's a nice action-adventure you're in for!

I'd rate this game somewhere in the area of a strong 7.6 and I do recommend this game.

So is this game for you?
It is if you're into the theme of ancient greek mythology, enjoy a hack n slash brawler-type gameplay and don't mind a heavy emphasis on story.

You'll recognize gameplay style and mechanics from games such as KOTOR, God of War and Mass Effect. A word of warning though, Rise of the Argonauts never really excels in either of the areas it has borrowed its style and mechanics from.
For example, the combat is nowhere near as fluid or satisfying as that you experience in God of War. The RPG elements and branching story mechanics is nowhere near as fleshed out as they are in KOTOR or Mass Effect.

Don't let that discourage you though, because even though the game doesn't reach the heights of some of its inspiration, what's there is well enough for you to see the journey through to the end. Also the games' setting, theme, story and characters are great and will keep you plenty entertained from start to finish.

Oh and I hate even bringing this subject up but I know that for some of you, it really matters a lot. I'm talking about the fact that the game isn't exactly the newest and it does show. At least if you allow yourself to compare it to modern games. Personally I think the visuals of the game are very pleasing and didn't impact my score of the game negatively in any way. With that said I do admit that it doesn't hold the standard of razor-sharp HD standards that we enjoy today. However if you let that get int the way of playing and enjoying this game then I can only say shame on you and may hades claim you!

Be aware:  the first 20-30 mins of the game is pretty bad, but once you speak to the gods, gain their boons and get to the Argo, the game gets progressively better.

I'm a sucker for ancient fables and had to try this game out because of the HumbleBundle. I recommend this game with EXTREME reservations.

PROS:
It has a good story, along with great voice acting and decent (if dated) graphics. Everything else is between bad and frustratingly bad, and I mean everything.

CONS:
The camera controls, especially on the final boss, made me realize how far we've come since it was released in 2008.
The graphics are decent, but even my up to date PC had some stuttering issues when it loaded new areas.
There is zero replay value in this game, unless you REALLY want to max out another skill tree.
When you are running around, forget being able to roll, pull a weapon or do anything to break the monotony of each sandaled footfall - THE ONLY THINGS YOU CAN DO ARE RUN AND INTERACT WITH SPECIFIC OBJECTS.
There is a LOT of running around in this game. So much running...and the map (at least using a 360 controller) is impossible to access without pausing the game and selecting the right option.
The menus are unwieldy and slow and you are forced to use them for everything.
There are no hidden items, no treasure chests.The only way to receive new equipment is to play through the dialogue selections correctly, wander into the right place, or simply progress the story.
The entire game is on rails. Need to hide out behind a rock? Nope, you can't leave the path.
Because you can't draw until there is a threat in front of you I frequently found myself surrounded by enemies before I was armed. That wasn't a problem because of my next point -
WAY too easy. Anyone who wasn't a boss died by the truckload, leaving behind nothing because there are no items to pick up. The deaths were brutal and each weapon had at least two different ones but after the first chapter I'd seen them all.
Too few types of enemies and again, I'd seen them all except the bosses by the end of the first level.

tl:dr - Good story hack 'n slash with very little customization, replayability, or variety. Basically, if you want to see a slight twist on the story of the Argonauts you should check it out. If not, don't bother downloading all 12gb and thank me later.

reviewText:
Rise of the Argonauts is a game that gets very little notice today. You play as Jason of Iolcus, king of ancient myth, whose wife Alceme is murdered by nefarious assassins. Instead of accepting her death, Jason sets out upon a journey across Greece in search of the one artifact that is reputedly able to reverse death: the Golden Fleece. Unique setting, fair graphics (Unreal 3), average voice-acting, good combat, and a fabulous soundtrack make this a niche classic.

After the death of Alceme at the beginning, Jason must venture to several places, looking for clues to the location of the Golden Fleece. Three of these locations – Mycenae, Kythra, and Saria - can be visited in any order, so there is the possibility to take different squad-mates with you depending on where you visit first (you can take two for a party size of three). After everyone has been gathered, you have the location of the Golden Fleece, and proceed linearly to the end of the game. The areas and levels themselves are large, but not very open. Not that there would have been anything gained by a sandbox design; but the levels generally feel narrow and restricted, save for the wide open arenas where the fighting occurs.

Rise of the Argonauts takes a serious, dramatic approach to Jason's classic tale. If that sounds like there is a lot of dialog in Rise of the Argonauts, there is. Everyone has conversation – and frequently, after finishing one discussion, you'll proceed to the next checkpoint only to have another conversation. There are branching dialog trees, and a few differing outcomes. But one place where Rise of the Argonauts falls beneath the others is in the quality of the voice-acting. It is serviceable, but not much else.

The combat is swift and fun, and will leave you wishing for more. Jason keeps his shield, and can choose from a sword, spear, or mace. Slow-motion finishing moves abound. Enemies tend to be easy once you've mastered dodge and block. Each of the upgrade trees “honors” a different Greek god, and your combat develops in the manner your favored  god prefers. I choose Hermes for most of my upgrades, resulting in quick, active combat that favors the sword and allowed Jason to call down lightning strikes and great winds as he fought and dispatched enemies. Ares, Apollo and Athena each have their own styles, buffs and debuffs. Find the right balance, and combat can almost be too easy. Until you get to the boss battles, that is. Enjoy slicing and dicing the minor minions of the underworld while you can; there will come a time when you'll have to face  six minotaurs at once – while fighting a boss...

Usually the soundtrack gets a passing mention of whether it is good or bad, but the music is one of the strongest parts of Rise of the Argonauts. Composer Tyler Bates channeled Troy and Gladiator and crafted a moving and intense score.

There is a lot of fun to be had with Rise of the Argonauts if a dialogue-driven hack 'n slash piques your interest (as it did mine). The use of Greek legend provides a great ambiance, and unique ways to upgrade and play give it some replay value, too. An easy game to recommend if you are looking for a change of pace.

reviewText:
Rise of the Argonauts is a good game, one which has a number of great ideas, but most of them fall a bit short, making the result come just a bit short of being an excellent game, though still a very enjoyable one.

I would say the basic idea the devs had was to make a story-driven, hack'n'slash action RPG, and in the end, apart from the RPG part which is great and unique, the other parts are weirdly meshed together and kind of underdevelpoped.

Let's start with the story, which tells a slightly modified version of the Greek legend of Jason and the Argonauts. In this version, Jason's bride Alceme is killed during their wedding, and Jason sets out to find the Golden Fleece in order to bring her back to life. The story is pretty straightforward, and being based on preexisting lore, you can immediately tell what will happen. But the writers manage to keep you invested with a number of interesting characters from Greek mythology whom Jason encounters along the way, and having all the elements you want from a Greek legend. You travel various colorful locations, meet and fight alongside heroes of legend, slay great beasts, and even take part in a philosophical debate(in my opinion, one of the best sections of the game).

Combat is your standard action h'n's deal. Light attack, heavy attack, dodge, block, parry. You have three weapons, a sword, a mace and a spear, each with its own strengths, weaknesses and a distinct playstyle. You can switch them on the fly, and over the course of your journey you will find better weapons, even ones blessed by the gods themselves which have special properties. The combat is pretty good, but it is way too easy. Even on hard, the game is ridiculously easy, unless you refuse to level up, in which case it gets boring, not hard, because you lack the damage to kill enemies with more health while being able to dodge all of their attacks.

Now, a bit on the RPG elements of the game, its by far best segment. This game has a really unique way of leveling up. Jason is favored by four gods: Ares, Apollo, Hermes and Athena. During conversations, all of your choices are favored by a certain god. Choosing one will grant you favor with that god, and once you accumulate enough favor, you earn an aspect point you can then invest in that god's skill tree. Also, the game keeps track of your deeds, which are a sort of achievements. You can devote these deeds to the gods in exchange for favor. It is a really unique take on XP, and I enjoyed it quite a lot. Also, the skills are varied and interesting, with each god granting you skills and powers which favor a certain playstyle reflective of his or her field of dominion.

Having discussed the three main aspect of the mix of genres this game covers, it's time to talk about how they work together, which is a bit...meh. The game's pacing and story/combat balance is really, really bad. There are lengthy sections where you do no combat at all, followed by either a short battle or a long, drawn out sequence of battles where enemies just keep on coming for you to oneshot. The story and combat don't really work together, they seem more like being thrown in together.

This is one of those cases where the whole is better than the sum of its parts. Though all of these elements have great ideas but more of an ok execution, and even work to mixed results together, the game as a whole is still really enjoyable. I had a blast with it, and the 12 hours I put in just flew by. Even with the easy combat, and bad pacing, I was never actually bored, and almost burned through it, without even noticing that I had played for that long, which is not something I can say for many other games.

Despite its flaws, I would highly recommend the game, especially if you are a fan of Greek mythology. You may not get the greatest of stories, or challenging combat, but you can have a great time, which shows that with fresh ideas, even an ok game can be a great experience.

reviewText:
I really enjoyed Rise of the Argonauts. Yes, it's quite easy and not very long, the plot is kind of stupid in places, the loading times disguised as cutscenes (I'm talking to you, gates to the Acropolis of Mycenae) become tedious because there's much running back and forth, and it's not the best looking game out there. Why did I like it then?

Well, I'm a sucker for Greek mythology and I think this game gets the atmosphere right. Mostly. Don't get me wrong, the mythical characters, places and stories of old are misplaced, mixed and butchered without remorse, when not completely made up. If you want a more canonical depiction of Greek myths go play Apotheon (seriously, go play it, it's awesome!), this is more like a fanfiction or an alternate reality but still feels Greek and mythical enough.

I especially like the god alignment system. Dialog options don't influence the plot but they do influence gameplay because your dialog choices are aligned with one of four deities (Athena, Apollo, Ares and Hermes). Winning their favour by choosing their dialogs or dedicating your deeds (ingame achievements) to them lets you level up in their respective skill trees and unlock different powers and buffs. To me it feels very satisfying to devote yourself to a god (Athena rules and anyone who disagrees will eat my spear), it really gets me immersed.

The dialogs and characters are mostly well written. Each of your companions (you can choose two of them to join you in each level, out of four that you recruit along the story) have different personalities, and they interact between them and with the enviroment in different ways (Pan is snarky and will go on about old legends and trivia, Achilles is obnoxious and will brag about being the best fighter ever, and so on)

The combat, although not very tricky, is fluid, fun and bloody, and can get quite spectacular once you start throwing god powers all over the place.

Aesthetically, it's good enough. Some of the enviroments look pretty and colorful, like Iolcus palace (I really liked the guards openning the doors for you, I know it's probably there just to hide a loading time but it made me feel like a king and I've seen too many magical self-openning doors in games to appreciate the detail), while others are much more dull and uninspired. The bronze in your armour is shiny and many of the armours and wepons themselves are not too overly fantastical in design, which I like.

I haven't experienced crashes or major bugs that I remember, as many reviews say, and I played for several hours at a time. I guess I got lucky. I bough this game on a sale for dirt cheap (1.75 EUR) fearing that it would be awful or crash on me, but I was pleasantly surprised and, after completing it, I woudn't mind having paid more for it.

reviewText:
Rise of the Argonauts is an action rpg set in ancient Greece.  You play the mythical hero Jason in search of the golden fleece, in an adventure filled with Greek mythology.  The story was entertaining and I enjoyed the recreation of ancient grease, it made the game seem more weighty than the typical fantasy fair, being grounded in earth history.  Gameplay wise it consists of lots of interesting conversations and side quests, as well as typical rock paper scissors combat.  There are several distinct play styles in combat which made for a nice change of pace.  There is plenty of choice in the conversations, but instead of the typically good vs bad vs neutral conversations trees this game basis the conversation topics on different gods.  Each of the 4 gods has a level up tree where you open up new abilities and bluffs, the deeds you complete and conversation choices you makes fills the appropriates God’s tree.  It’s a fresh and different take on conversation and quests and I really enjoyed this aspect of the game.

Overall I really enjoyed my time with Jason and his Argonauts.  Unfortunately I can’t recommend this game as during conversations it kept randomly crashing to desktop.  It started periodically at first, and then grew in rate to the point of crashing every few conversations, making the game basically unplayable.  I tried a few of the fixes I found in steam forums and online but none of it solved the crashing.  Overall Rise of the Argonauts is a really great hidden Gem RPG, but it’s very buggy to the point of being unplayable.  A search of the forums in steam will show I am far from the only one with this experience.

reviewText:
This game would have been a lot better if there had been more combat. Seriously, only like 1/3 of the game was actual combat, while the rest was just walking around and talking to people, which gets tedious really quickly.
Not that the combat was anything spectacular, just your standard hack'n'slash fare, only really, really easy. The enemies spend a lot of the time standing there and letting you attack them, i literally never used the block button. And if you do get down to low health, you can just walk away for a few seconds and your health regenerates. I didn't die until the final boss fight, and that's only because it took me a while to figure out how i was supposed to kill him.
The only real positive was the interesting character progression system, where you complete deeds (save a villager, kill X enemies, etc.) and then dedicate those deeds to one of four gods to gain favour with those gods, and gaining enough favour with a specific god grants you a skill point to spend on that god's skill tree, with each god representing a different combat style.
The story was OK, but the whole plot of the myth has been completely changed (instead of collecting the Fleece to restore his fathers kingdom, Jason only wants it to resurrect his dead wife) and all the characters are there, but they are completely different from their mythic counterparts, especially Medea, who instead of being a key part of the story, is just another Argonaut.
All in all it was a pretty average game, but being a big fan of Greek myth i found it mildly enjoyable, despite being annoyed by the changes from the myth. However, I can't recommend it given how most of the game is spent in boring conversations. If there had been more action, I would recommend it, but sadly, there isn't enough to keep the game interesting.
I also encountered frequent crashes at seemingly random points, but I can't say for sure if it's the game or my computer. However given that i can play more recent and far more graphically demanding titles than this, it seems likely that it's the game that's at fault.

reviewText: Rise of the Argonauts is an underrated gem. It's one of those rare games where the well written and told story motivates you. The characters are interesting. Jason of Iolcus, is the Commander Shepherd of this game, the character you plays with. He is a fair minded King eager to find a way to bring back his wife from the dead. The other characters are memorable and each has a unique trait you may like or dislike them. Each quest is memorable and finally you have to do more than picking up ten flowers, which is usually the basic quests for most AAA RPGs. The combat is simple, but entertaining with all three weapon types (Spear, Sword and Maul). And the skill system, along with Goddess Athena and the Gods, Ares, Hermes, Apollo, is very interesting. Finally a game which does not have the standard XP system, but it's something new. You have to offer your completed quest deeds to these Gods to evolve. And strange, but I really enjoyed the last boss fight (Some may find it easy, but I liked it.). Unfortunately the game has some bugs and loves to crash to desktop (If it does, presumably you have more core than one. In that case CTRL-ALT-DEL after you start the game, select the game's exe in the Task Manager and set the Affinity to one CPU. Then go back to the game and it won't CTD anymore.). But other than this little problem, it's a really great game, reminds me for my other favorite, Titan Quest, just in TPS. Rise of the Argonatus is highly recommended for those who love games based on the Greek Mythology.
